fields.bodyText: Europe's stock markets finished up, although not very dramatically, as traders eye up Friday's US jobs data (the non-farm payroll for May). As you'll see, though, shares are down slightly on Wall Street -- after twenty consecutive Tuesdays when the Dow Jones ended higher. And the euro is all but flat today, at €1.3068. Here's Kit Juckes of Soc Gen's take on the markets: The story of Monday was that bad US data were good for equities, bad for the dollar, calming for a world woried of Fed normalisation. We will see Fed 'taper fear' ebb and flow all summer. This morning we saw the RBA leave rates on hold but suggest they will ease further, and sound bearish of their currency, whose short-covering rally was small and is over. And in Japan, stronger wage growth is just good news for Abenomics and Japan. I's a low volume, quiet day. Treasury yields and equities are flat and the dollar up a bit. I think we can mark time till payrolls, but I think rallies in Treasuries will find willing sellers and the reaction to 'good NFP' would be bigger than to 'bad NFP'. The Taper-debate rumbles but it's a question of when, not if poliicy gets less easy. That's probably the lesson from recent 'mixed' data; I meet plenty of people who think any talk of US rate normalisation is premature, but nearly all concede 'new normal neutral' is much higher than here. That's a recipe for a bearish Tsy, bullish USD, cautious credit bias and also for higher vol. Europe is basking in the soft glow of yesterday's slightly better data. Euro bears are once again weary. The news that the pace of decline in economic activity is slowing, is hardly reason to break out the champagne, and all we can really look forward to is more incremental easing from the ECB. That reminds me that Helianthe, Hoth25, zerozero and nocolours had a good banter this morning over the issue of whether bad data is good for the markets -- read it here. And with that, I'm off. Cheers all, back tomorrow. Thanks for reading, and for the comments. GW Troika officials were reminded of the public unhappiness over Greece's economic situation as they began their latest assessment of the country's economy. A group of retired seamen held a demonstration in front of their healthcare fund building in Piraeus, to protest against benefit cuts, as these two photos show: Seperately, a survey by the Washington-based Pew Research Center found that 99% of Greeks believe the country’s economic situation is very or somewhat bad. Two-thirds think their generation will experience an easier time than the next one. However, as Kathimerini reports, other countries are more pessimistic: When asked about how they see their children's futures, 67% said they expect the next generation to be worse off than their parents, coming fifth on the scale behind Japan, Britain and Italy. This scale is topped by France, where 90% saw a bleak future for the next generation. Former Goldman Sachs executive Fabrice Tourre has failed in an attempt to have elements of a fraud case over the controversial Abacus case thrown out. A US district judge rejected Tourre's argument that the case against him should be 'narrowed' because he was working outside the US for Goldman during the time covered by the SEC's case. Katherine Forrest ruled that the SEC was due to 'partial summary judgement'. The civil fraud trial will begin in mid-July, Reuters reports. Abacus was a CDO (collateralised debt obligation), or mortgage-backed security, which Goldman created and sold to clients."Fabulous Fab" Tourre hit the headlines when he faced a congressional commitee after the SEC sued Goldman (details here). Amid signs of some economic revival in the UK, Duncan Weldon of the TUC has drawn up 10 questions – asking how the country could build a truly sustainable recovery: He's looking for answers on his blog. Here are the questions: How can we ensure that the rewards from growth actually benefit most people? The danger here is a repeat of the situation between 2003-2008, when despite decent headline growth, median wages for those in the middle and below barely budged. How can we reduce our dependence on the financial sector as a driver of growth? How can we ensure that there is more economic activity throughout the UK rather than too much being concentrated in the South East pocket? How can we increase investment levels in the UK? In particular, how can we increase private business investment? What can be done about the UK’s poor balance of payments? How can we ensure that we have a diverse and resilient tax base? How can we better manage the credit cycle? How do we tackle long term unemployment and ensure that more people have access to the labour market? In other words, how do we get back to something reassembling full employment? Why is youth unemployment so high? What is a proper balance between fiscal, monetary and macroprudential policy and how should that balance be managed? Those of you based abroad may have particularly useful insights. No need to answer all 10 questions, I imagine. Just click here... On the EC-China solar panels dispute (3pm onwards), our Europe editor Ian Traynor reports that the Commissions says the dispute is less about dumping than fundamentally scrutinising China's trade practices and its commercial relations with Europe. This means there is a lot at stake, Ian explains: De Gucht argues that the big danger facing Europe is that it will fail to stand up to China unless it stands together. But Germany, by far China's biggest trading partner in the EU, is fiercely opposed to the imposition of tarriffs. Only last week Chancellor Angela Merkel said that this was not the way to resolve the dispute. It is very rare indeed for the Commission to launch such a major trade dispute, the biggest ever, against the wishes of the EU's biggest exporter. The full text of the EC's announcement on new duties for Chinese solar panel makers (see 3pm) are online here: Remarks by EU Trade Commissioner Karel De Gucht on the decision to impose provisional anti-dumping measures on imports of solar panels from China Here's De Gucht's conclusion: Let me end by once again stressing that I would prefer a negotiated solution and quickly – there is no reason for this to last months if there is a sincere desire by our Chinese partners to seek a solution through 'price-undertakings.' But it is the role of Chinese exporters and the Chinese Chamber of Commerce to now step forward with a solution that removes the injury to the European solar panel industry. I look forward to engaging with them as soon as possible so we can work together to reach a satisfactory settlement which will be beneficial for all of us. Despite EU politicians asking it not to provoke a trade war with China, the European Commission has annnounced new 'anti-dumping' duties on solar panel makers. In the last few minutes the EU trade chief, Karel De Gucht, announced that the Chinese solar panel industry will face a 11.8% levy on imports into the EU. That's a lower rate than some had expected. However, it will jump to 47.6% unless the two sides can reach a new deal by August – suggesting concessions have been made in an attempt to get China to the negotiating table. De Gucht told a press conference in Brussels that the ball was in China's court now. He is adamant that Chinese firms have been unfairly driving EU competitors out of business by dumping unfairly subsidised products on the European market. Some European leaders, though, had urged the EC to hold back from imposing levies. Led by Germany, they feared retaliatory action at a time when the eurozone needs to boost its trade links to escape recession, and is looking for investment from China. There is an irony in Brussels opening hostilities with Beijing hours after Christine Lagarde urges Greece to find more foreign investment (see 12.23pm). France, though, has supported imposing new duties on China – making it harder for the Commission to avoid today's announcement. And De Gucht insists that Chinese solar panels are unfairly cheap. De Gucht also denied caving into pressure from some member states to impose a low levy for the first few weeks -- although the initial level of 11.8% does look like a concession: Over in America, the trade deficit has widened as a rise in imports outpaced exports in April. The US trade gap hit $40.29bn on a seasonally adjusted basis, following a 2.4% rise in exports to $227.7bn and a 1.2% rise in imports to $187.4bn. That's an increase on March's $37.13bn, but a slightly smaller rise than expected. The data also included import and export data by region. It's not seasonally adjusted, and showed some sharp swings: EXPORTS BY COUNTRY/REGION, UNADJUSTED Canada: +0.6% Mexico: +10.7% EU: -7.9% China: -4.7% Japan: -9.3% South/Central America: -8.6% Brazil: -9.4% OPEC: -15.5% IMPORTS BY COUNTRY/REGION, UNADJUSTED Canada: +1.0% Mexico: +4.7% EU: +2.2% China: +21.2% Japan: -1.1% South/Central America: +1.8% Brazil: +8.4% OPEC: + 6.7 • • • • However, Spring data can be particularly volatile due to holidays (such as Easter, and China's Spring Festival) which disrupt the usual patterns of trade. Marc Ostwald of Monument Securities said the data suggested weakness in April due to weak exports to EU and China, adding: But treat all of this with care, seasonals and revisions suggest extrapolating to underlying trends would be premature! Peer Steinbrück, the social democrat's challenger to Angela Merkel in this autumn's elections, has called for a new Marshall Plan for Europe, to help its weakest members return to growth. The SPD's Chancellor candidate told the Free University of Berlin in Berlin that the package would help countries which have been racked by austerity measures since the financial crisis began. There's a hitch, though. The plan would be financed, Steinbrück suggsted, by financial transactions – something Europe appears to be inching away from. Here's AP's take: The man who is challenging Angela Merkel to become chancellor of Germany has called for a new Marshall Plan to revive Europe’s ailing economies. Peer Steinbrueck said in his first major foreign policy speech Tuesday at Berlin’s Free University that such a program could be funded in part by new taxes on financial transactions. He added that the government’s insistence on budget austerity in Europe is creating economic stagnation. Steinbrueck’s Social Democratic Party is trailing Merkel’s Christian Democrats in the polls three months before the Sept. 22 general election. The former finance minister said countries like Greece and Portugal need a massive plan similar to the one that rebuilt Germany after World War II to avoid a “diabolical spiral” toward further joblessness and economic stagnation. However, it appears that the German government has been working on another issue today. According to Bloomberg, Berlin has won Paris's backing to delay giving the European Stability Mechanism full powers to recapitalise banks, possibly until 2015. Christine Lagarde has repeated her call for Greece's government to push on with economic reforms to encourage foreign investors, and to keep fighting tax evasion, as inspectors from the Troika arrive back in Athens for (yet) another assessment of its economy. Speaking to state TV, IMF chief Lagarde argued that Greece was 'pretty much on track', although some way from the end. Athens mustn't stop, she argued. Asked if she agrees that Greece is becoming a "success story" (as prime minister Samaras claimed), Lagarde wasn't completely convinced, saying: I certainly hope it's on its way to being a success story. She added: There are some really positive developments but obviously more needs to be done. There has been significant improvement with a programme that is now pretty much on track. The programme has seen massive, unprecedented consolidation, which is hard. That 'effort' is clear in the latest jobless data, with a quarter of people officially unemployed (or 60%-plus for young people). That's why the IMF is pushing for foreign investment -- consumer spending is hardly going to drive a recovery (although exports could help, if economic growth elsewhere picks up). Last week's jump in Greek economic confidence is an encouraging sign for the Troika, whose visit has begun by highlighting the issue of job cuts across the public sector. Athens has agreed to cut 15,000 civil servants by the end of 2014, but is pushing for more time. Kathimerini has more details: Although Athens is committed to the agreed target of sacking 4,000 public sector workers by the end of the year, it wants to avoid stirring up union opposition during what is expected to be a prosperous summer for the tourism sector. Today, the Administrative Reform Ministry will have to hand over to the troika details of the process to sack civil servants accused and then convicted of offenses such as breach of faith, accepting bribes and taking leave without permission. It is estimated that hundreds of these public servants will be among the 15,000 that have to be fired by next year. Meanwhile, our economics leader writer, Aditya Chakrabortty, has dsismissed the talk of Greece's 'success story' as premature, and self-serving: What's at stake here is a much bigger prize than whether an economy worth 2% of Europe's annual GDP really is on the mend. It's about justifying the shock therapy imposed on distressed members of the eurozone. Building materials firm Wolseley isn't joining today's market rally. It's shares are down almost 4% this morning, with construction delays in France overshadowing improvements in the UK and US. The firm (whose products include plumbing and heating kit) warned that market conditions remain challenging in the rest of Europe. As my colleague Nick Fletcher explains: The company reported a 7.9% rise in third quarter trading profits to £150m, with good growth in the US and UK. But investors took more notice of Europe, where its business continues to suffer from the continuing economic crisis. Sales in France fell by 9.2% on a like for like basis due to weak residential construction, and by 4.6% in central Europe. More details and reaction here: Confirmation this morning that while the eurozone has many problems, inflation isn't one of them. Factory gate prices – basically, what companies pay for their raw materials and components – fell by 0.6% in April, the biggest month-on-month decrease since July 2009 Energy prices in the euro zone dropped by 1.6 percent in April from March - the biggest decline since July 2009 - and making for a fall of 2.0 percent compared to the same month a year ago. Producer proces fell across the eurozone's biggest countries. Reuters has the details: Producer prices fell in all core euro zone countries measured on the monthly basis, with Germany showing a 0.2 percent decline, the third monthly fall in a row, and France recording a 0.9 percent drop. No reason here for the European Central Bank to worry about inflationary pressures at this week's governing council meeting.... UPDATE: Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight agrees: The ECB’s main focus will remain on ways of facilitating getting more credit through to smaller companies. The ECB continues to look closely into the case for a negative deposit rate, although we are doubtful that it will go down this route. And this graph shows how UK housebuilding activity outpaced the commercial and civil engineering sectors last month (see 10.14am): Britain's construction sector returned to growth after six months of contraction in May, but new homes – rather than infrastructure projects – was the cause. Markit reported a "robust and accelerated" expansion of residential housebuilding in Britain. Its UK construction PMI (a survey of conditions across the sector) rose to 50.8 in May, indicating a rise in activity, from April's 49.4, a small fall. Residential housebuilding activity hit a 26-month high. However, spenging on commercial and civil engineering actually declined again, despite the UK economy returning to growth this year. That, Markit warned, was a drag on growth. David Noble, chief executive officer at the Chartered Institute of Purchasing & Supply, said the figures showed the impact of the UK government's efforts to stimulate the housing sector (such as its much-criticised Help to Buy scheme), and the urgent need for more larger infrastructure schemes. Noble said: The construction sector seems to have turned a corner after six dismal months. The improvement has been fuelled by a boon in house building, but the sector remains bogged down by contractions in commercial construction and civil engineering. Whilst confidence for the year ahead remains high, the poor performance of suppliers and flat levels of employment will serve as a reality check to construction and the wider UK economy. The Government’s attempts to boost house building has given months of lacklustre growth a shot in the arm, but the continued decline in civil engineering can be largely attributed to the lack of public sector projects, which show no sign of increasing. This, coupled with poor performance in the commercial sector, means house building alone is driving industry growth. Here's the release. Many experts have warned that Help to Buy will drive up house prices, pricing younger people out of the market. Sir Mervyn King, the outgoing governor of the Bank of England, has insisted the plan must remain temporary. And last month the International Monetary Fund waded in, warning that the plan would fail to improve access to housing. The warning came as the IMF also called for infrastructure projects to be accelerated to help the economy. Financial blogger @pawelmorski was so alarmed by Help to Buy that he suggested last week that Osborne must be a Communist mole: UK: Agent Gideon Goes Rogue. And Societe Generale's analyst, Albert Edwards, has also laid into Osborne for burdening young people with even more debt. Why don't we call this policy by the name it really is, namely the indentured servitude of our young people? Overnight, Australia's central bank surprised few people by leaving interest rates unchanged (at 2.75%). The Reserve Bank of Australia took the decision to sit tight after concluding that there were "reasonable prospects of a pick-up" in global economic growth in 2014. Last month that RBA made an unexpected rate cut. But as governor Glenn Stevens explained: The Board judged that the easier financial conditions now in place will contribute to a strengthening of growth over time, consistent with achieving the inflation target. It decided that the stance of monetary policy remained appropriate for the time being. The Board also judged that the inflation outlook, as currently assessed, may provide some scope for further easing, should that be required to support demand. The RBA also commented that the Australian dollar has fallen in value in recent weeks, but still remains high by historical terms -- showing they aren't ignoring the impact of currency fluctuations. Here's the full statement Obviously the RBA hasn't been forced into the kind of electronic money-printing that alarms the likes of BIS. But that final sentence shows that the RBA is still thinking about relaxing monetary policy, not tightening. Janu Chan, economist at ST George's Bank, said the door had been left open to another rate cut: Given the uncertainty surrounding the labour force, business investment and the path of the Australian dollar, there is that possibility that they might cut rates again. Especially if the RBA's assessment of the global economy proves too bullish, amid concern over China's growth prospects. As Fast FT asked this morning, is Australia's central bank too optimistic? City analysts confirm that we're in a topsy turvy world where bad economic news is good for share prices -- thus today's little rally after yesterday's weak US manufacturing data (see 8.57am). Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, explained that London share prices had been "helped by - wait for it – poor US data, reducing recently heightened fears the US Fed could taper its QE3 asset purchase programme soon". Matt Basi of CMC Markets makes the same point in his morning note: The possibility that Federal Reserve quantitative easing will continue at full throttle for some time to come has been the key driver for world markets over the past day. Ironically, a much weaker than expected ISM manufacturing index in the US led to a stock market rally. Markets reasoned that although the manufacturing sector accounts for only 10-12% of US GDP, an ISM reading of 49.0 (the weakest since 2009) would see Fed stimulus left in place. Yesterday morning was dominated by better-than-expected manufacturing data from Europe, which had no obvious effect on stock prices at all... European investors have shaken off the prospect of the end to electronic money-printing, pushing shares higher this morning. BIS chief Jaime Caruana's warning that unwinding the world's huge quantitative easing programmes may not be smooth (see 8.12am) hasn't caused alarm. Instead, traders are anticipating that the Federal Reserve will maintain its stimulus programmes. Yesterday's weak ISM manufacturing survey, which suggested the US recovery was faltering, is being taken as a sign that Ben Bernanke won't start tightening.... There's also relief that Japan's Nikkei climbed by 2% overnight, reversing some of its recent heavy falls. • FTSE 100: up 38 points at 6564, +0.6% • German DAX: up 67 at 8353, +0.8% • French CAC: up 26 points at 3927, +0.7% • Spanish IBEX: up 82 points at 8367, +1% • Italian FTSE MIB: up 199 points at 17257, +1.1% Just in, the number of people out of work in Spain fell by almost 100,000 last month. Data released by the Spanish Labour Ministry showed the biggest ever fall in registered jobless for any May. Registered unemployment dropped by 98,265 people, or 1.97%, lowering the total out of work to 4,890,928. May is typically a good month for employment, with the start of the tourism season meaning more temporary hiring (this data isn't seasonally adjusted). But still, the size of the bounceback is a welcome surprise. In an average May, unemployment drops by around 55k. The figures showed that unemployment fell across the economy, and for both men (-2.4%) and women (-1.47%). Most encouraging, youth unemployment fell by 16,735 people (-3.53%) from the previous month. Spain's secretary of state for employment, Engracia Hidalgo, welcomed the news, and said the Madrid government was committed to delivering a strong economic recovery. Here's the full statement: El paro registrado ha bajado en 98.265 personas, el mayor descenso en un mes de mayo. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events across the eurozone and the global economy. First up... the world's financial markets could face stormy conditions when central banks begin to tighten monetary policy, the head of the Bank of International Settlements has warned this morning. BIS chief Jaime Caruana said investors and governments need to be ready for rough times. Speaking in Seoul this morning, the general manager of the so-called "central bankers’ bank" warned: While central banks surely have all the tools necessary to technically engineer an exit and will doubtless do their utmost to communicate properly with market participants, it cannot be taken for granted that the process will be smooth. Many financial institutions, he warned, could suffer significant losses when central banks decide to return to normality and end their government bond purchase schemes. As Caruana put it: Authorities and market participants must recognise the challenges inherent in the inevitable and desirable interest rate normalisation and seek to make their financial firms and markets resilient in the face of potential strains. The speech comes at a time when the world markets are being heavily influenced by speculation over America's stimulus package. Talk of the Federal Reserve 'tapering' its huge quantitative easing programme this summer have driven shares down, while bad economic news has often pushed shares up because further stimulus has looked more likely. Caruana is worried that those QE packages have driven bond prices up to unsustainable levels where investors don't actualiy get a return for holding the debt. As he puts it: The term premium – the extra reward for bearing the price risk and inflation risk of holding a fixed rate bond – has flipped into a penalty that the investor must pay. This graph shows that holding US and German 10-year debt means a guaranteed loss, once inflation is factored in: Once QE is unwound, those yields will rise as prices fall -- and the impact on banks could be painful, Caruana warned: A global steepening of yield curves could hit the capital of financial institutions, to the extent that they hold their government’s debt, and worsen debt sustainability. Caruana's speech is online here: Global liquidity: where do we stand? (including plenty of other graphs). It's the latest in a series of warnings from BIS over the era of ultra-loose monetary policy. Last month, the global banking body suggested that QE had gone far enough. As usual, I'll be tracking the latest events through the day....

Europe is basking in the soft glow of yesterday's slightly better data. Euro bears are once again weary. The news that the pace of decline in economic activity is slowing, is hardly reason to break out the champagne, and all we can really look forward to is more incremental easing from the ECB.

That reminds me that Helianthe, Hoth25, zerozero and nocolours had a good banter this morning over the issue of whether bad data is good for the markets -- read it here.

And with that, I'm off. Cheers all, back tomorrow. Thanks for reading, and for the comments. GW

5.10pm BST

Key event

Troika officials were reminded of the public unhappiness over Greece's economic situation as they began their latest assessment of the country's economy.

A group of retired seamen held a demonstration in front of their healthcare fund building in Piraeus, to protest against benefit cuts, as these two photos show:

When asked about how they see their children's futures, 67% said they expect the next generation to be worse off than their parents, coming fifth on the scale behind Japan, Britain and Italy.

This scale is topped by France, where 90% saw a bleak future for the next generation.

4.44pm BST

Former Goldman Sachs executive Fabrice Tourre has failed in an attempt to have elements of a fraud case over the controversial Abacus case thrown out.

A US district judge rejected Tourre's argument that the case against him should be 'narrowed' because he was working outside the US for Goldman during the time covered by the SEC's case.

Katherine Forrest ruled that the SEC was due to 'partial summary judgement'. The civil fraud trial will begin in mid-July, Reuters reports.

Can you help?

Amid signs of some economic revival in the UK, Duncan Weldon of the TUC has drawn up 10 questions – asking how the country could build a truly sustainable recovery:

He's looking for answers on his blog. Here are the questions:

Updated at 4.08pm BST

3.40pm BST

Ian Traynor: Lots at stake in solar panal dispute

On the EC-China solar panels dispute (3pm onwards), our Europe editor Ian Traynor reports that the Commissions says the dispute is less about dumping than fundamentally scrutinising China's trade practices and its commercial relations with Europe.

This means there is a lot at stake, Ian explains:

De Gucht argues that the big danger facing Europe is that it will
fail to stand up to China unless it stands together. But Germany, by far China's biggest trading partner in the EU, is fiercely opposed to the imposition of tarriffs. Only last week Chancellor Angela Merkel said that this was not the way to resolve the dispute.

It is very rare indeed for the Commission to launch such a major trade dispute, the biggest ever, against the wishes of the EU's biggest exporter.

3.28pm BST

The full text of the EC's announcement on new duties for Chinese solar panel makers (see 3pm) are online here:

Remarks by EU Trade Commissioner Karel De Gucht on the decision to impose provisional anti-dumping measures on imports of solar panels from China

Here's De Gucht's conclusion:

Let me end by once again stressing that I would prefer a negotiated solution and quickly – there is no reason for this to last months if there is a sincere desire by our Chinese partners to seek a solution through 'price-undertakings.' But it is the role of Chinese exporters and the Chinese Chamber of Commerce to now step forward with a solution that removes the injury to the European solar panel industry.

I look forward to engaging with them as soon as possible so we can work together to reach a satisfactory settlement which will be beneficial for all of us.

3.00pm BST

EC hits China's solar panel firms with anti-dumping duties

Despite EU politicians asking it not to provoke a trade war with China, the European Commission has annnounced new 'anti-dumping' duties on solar panel makers.

In the last few minutes the EU trade chief, Karel De Gucht, announced that the Chinese solar panel industry will face a 11.8% levy on imports into the EU.

That's a lower rate than some had expected. However, it will jump to 47.6% unless the two sides can reach a new deal by August – suggesting concessions have been made in an attempt to get China to the negotiating table.

De Gucht told a press conference in Brussels that the ball was in China's court now. He is adamant that Chinese firms have been unfairly driving EU competitors out of business by dumping unfairly subsidised products on the European market.

Some European leaders, though, had urged the EC to hold back from imposing levies. Led by Germany, they feared retaliatory action at a time when the eurozone needs to boost its trade links to escape recession, and is looking for investment from China.

There is an irony in Brussels opening hostilities with Beijing hours after Christine Lagarde urges Greece to find more foreign investment (see 12.23pm).

France, though, has supported imposing new duties on China – making it harder for the Commission to avoid today's announcement. And De Gucht insists that Chinese solar panels are unfairly cheap.

De Gucht also denied caving into pressure from some member states to impose a low levy for the first few weeks -- although the initial level of 11.8% does look like a concession:

Updated at 2.16pm BST

1.39pm BST

Steinbrück calls for Marshall Plan for eurozone

Peer Steinbrück, the social democrat's challenger to Angela Merkel in this autumn's elections, has called for a new Marshall Plan for Europe, to help its weakest members return to growth.

The SPD's Chancellor candidate told the Free University of Berlin in Berlin that the package would help countries which have been racked by austerity measures since the financial crisis began.

There's a hitch, though. The plan would be financed, Steinbrück suggsted, by financial transactions – something Europe appears to be inching away from.

Here's AP's take:

The man who is challenging Angela Merkel to become chancellor of Germany has called for a new Marshall Plan to revive Europe’s ailing economies.

Peer Steinbrueck said in his first major foreign policy speech Tuesday at Berlin’s Free University that such a program could be funded in part by new taxes on financial transactions.

He added that the government’s insistence on budget austerity in Europe is creating economic stagnation.

Steinbrueck’s Social Democratic Party is trailing Merkel’s Christian Democrats in the polls three months before the Sept. 22 general election.

The former finance minister said countries like Greece and Portugal need a massive plan similar to the one that rebuilt Germany after World War II to avoid a “diabolical spiral” toward further joblessness and economic stagnation.

However, it appears that the German government has been working on another issue today. According to Bloomberg, Berlin has won Paris's backing to delay giving the European Stability Mechanism full powers to recapitalise banks, possibly until 2015.

12.23pm BST

IMF tells Greece: don't stop now

Christine Lagarde has repeated her call for Greece's government to push on with economic reforms to encourage foreign investors, and to keep fighting tax evasion, as inspectors from the Troika arrive back in Athens for (yet) another assessment of its economy.

Speaking to state TV, IMF chief Lagarde argued that Greece was 'pretty much on track', although some way from the end. Athens mustn't stop, she argued.

Asked if she agrees that Greece is becoming a "success story" (as prime minister Samaras claimed), Lagarde wasn't completely convinced, saying:

I certainly hope it's on its way to being a success story.

She added:

There are some really positive developments but obviously more needs to be done.

There has been significant improvement with a programme that is now pretty much on track. The programme has seen massive, unprecedented consolidation, which is hard.

That 'effort' is clear in the latest jobless data, with a quarter of people officially unemployed (or 60%-plus for young people). That's why the IMF is pushing for foreign investment -- consumer spending is hardly going to drive a recovery (although exports could help, if economic growth elsewhere picks up).

Last week's jump in Greek economic confidence is an encouraging sign for the Troika, whose visit has begun by highlighting the issue of job cuts across the public sector. Athens has agreed to cut 15,000 civil servants by the end of 2014, but is pushing for more time.

Kathimerini has more details:

Although Athens is committed to the agreed target of sacking 4,000 public sector workers by the end of the year, it wants to avoid stirring up union opposition during what is expected to be a prosperous summer for the tourism sector.

Today, the Administrative Reform Ministry will have to hand over to the troika details of the process to sack civil servants accused and then convicted of offenses such as breach of faith, accepting bribes and taking leave without permission. It is estimated that hundreds of these public servants will be among the 15,000 that have to be fired by next year.

Meanwhile, our economics leader writer, Aditya Chakrabortty, has dsismissed the talk of Greece's 'success story' as premature, and self-serving:

What's at stake here is a much bigger prize than whether an economy worth 2% of Europe's annual GDP really is on the mend. It's about justifying the shock therapy imposed on distressed members of the eurozone.

11.16am BST

Europe problems chill Wolseley

Building materials firm Wolseley isn't joining today's market rally. It's shares are down almost 4% this morning, with construction delays in France overshadowing improvements in the UK and US.

The firm (whose products include plumbing and heating kit) warned that market conditions remain challenging in the rest of Europe.

As my colleague Nick Fletcher explains:

The company reported a 7.9% rise in third quarter trading profits to £150m, with good growth in the US and UK.

More details and reaction here:

10.54am BST

Confirmation this morning that while the eurozone has many problems, inflation isn't one of them.

Factory gate prices – basically, what companies pay for their raw materials and components – fell by 0.6% in April, the biggest month-on-month decrease since July 2009

Energy prices in the euro zone dropped by 1.6 percent in April from March - the biggest decline since July 2009 - and making for a fall of 2.0 percent compared to the same month a year ago.

Producer proces fell across the eurozone's biggest countries. Reuters has the details:

Producer prices fell in all core euro zone countries measured on the monthly basis, with Germany showing a 0.2 percent decline, the third monthly fall in a row, and France recording a 0.9 percent drop.

No reason here for the European Central Bank to worry about inflationary pressures at this week's governing council meeting....

UPDATE: Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight agrees:

The ECB’s main focus will remain on ways of facilitating getting more credit through to smaller companies. The ECB continues to look closely into the case for a negative deposit rate, although we are doubtful that it will go down this route.

Updated at 10.57am BST

10.26am BST

And this graph shows how UK housebuilding activity outpaced the commercial and civil engineering sectors last month (see 10.14am):

10.14am BST

The Osborne effect? Housebuilding delivers UK construction growth

Britain's construction sector returned to growth after six months of contraction in May, but new homes – rather than infrastructure projects – was the cause.

Markit reported a "robust and accelerated" expansion of residential housebuilding in Britain. Its UK construction PMI (a survey of conditions across the sector) rose to 50.8 in May, indicating a rise in activity, from April's 49.4, a small fall.

Residential housebuilding activity hit a 26-month high. However, spenging on commercial and civil engineering actually declined again, despite the UK economy returning to growth this year. That, Markit warned, was a drag on growth.

David Noble, chief executive officer at the Chartered Institute of Purchasing & Supply, said the figures showed the impact of the UK government's efforts to stimulate the housing sector (such as its much-criticised Help to Buy scheme), and the urgent need for more larger infrastructure schemes.

Noble said:

The construction sector seems to have turned a corner after six dismal months. The improvement has been fuelled by a boon in house building, but the sector remains bogged down by contractions in commercial construction and civil engineering.

Whilst confidence for the year ahead remains high, the poor performance of suppliers and flat levels of employment will serve as a reality check to construction and the wider UK economy.

The Government’s attempts to boost house building has given months of lacklustre growth a shot in the arm, but the continued decline in civil engineering can be largely attributed to the lack of public sector projects, which show no sign of increasing. This, coupled with poor performance in
the commercial sector, means house building alone is driving industry growth.

Here's the release.

Many experts have warned that Help to Buy will drive up house prices, pricing younger people out of the market. Sir Mervyn King, the outgoing governor of the Bank of England, has insisted the plan must remain temporary.

And last month the International Monetary Fund waded in, warning that the plan would fail to improve access to housing. The warning came as the IMF also called for infrastructure projects to be accelerated to help the economy.

Financial blogger @pawelmorski was so alarmed by Help to Buy that he suggested last week that Osborne must be a Communist mole: UK: Agent Gideon Goes Rogue.

And Societe Generale's analyst, Albert Edwards, has also laid into Osborne for burdening young people with even more debt.

Why don't we call this policy by the name it really is, namely the indentured servitude of our young people?

Updated at 10.48am BST

9.41am BST

Australian rates held, but for how long?...

Overnight, Australia's central bank surprised few people by leaving interest rates unchanged (at 2.75%).

The Reserve Bank of Australia took the decision to sit tight after concluding that there were "reasonable prospects of a pick-up" in global economic growth in 2014.

Last month that RBA made an unexpected rate cut. But as governor Glenn Stevens explained:

The Board judged that the easier financial conditions now in place will contribute to a strengthening of growth over time, consistent with achieving the inflation target. It decided that the stance of monetary policy remained appropriate for the time being.

The Board also judged that the inflation outlook, as currently assessed, may provide some scope for further easing, should that be required to support demand.

The RBA also commented that the Australian dollar has fallen in value in recent weeks, but still remains high by historical terms -- showing they aren't ignoring the impact of currency fluctuations. Here's the full statement

Obviously the RBA hasn't been forced into the kind of electronic money-printing that alarms the likes of BIS. But that final sentence shows that the RBA is still thinking about relaxing monetary policy, not tightening.

Janu Chan, economist at ST George's Bank, said the door had been left open to another rate cut:

Given the uncertainty surrounding the labour force, business investment and the path of the Australian dollar, there is that possibility that they might cut rates again.

Especially if the RBA's assessment of the global economy proves too bullish, amid concern over China's growth prospects. As Fast FT asked this morning, is Australia's central bank too optimistic?

Updated at 10.49am BST

9.12am BST

Analysts: Weak US manufacturing data = share rally

City analysts confirm that we're in a topsy turvy world where bad economic news is good for share prices -- thus today's little rally after yesterday's weak US manufacturing data (see 8.57am).

Mike van Dulken, head of research at Accendo Markets, explained that London share prices had been "helped by - wait for it – poor US data, reducing recently heightened fears the US Fed could taper its QE3 asset purchase programme soon". 

Matt Basi of CMC Markets makes the same point in his morning note:

The possibility that Federal Reserve quantitative easing will continue at full throttle for some time to come has been the key driver for world markets over the past day.

Ironically, a much weaker than expected ISM manufacturing index in the US led to a stock market rally. Markets reasoned that although the manufacturing sector accounts for only 10-12% of US GDP, an ISM reading of 49.0 (the weakest since 2009) would see Fed stimulus left in place.

Yesterday morning was dominated by better-than-expected manufacturing data from Europe, which had no obvious effect on stock prices at all...

8.57am BST

European markets up as QE fears fade

European investors have shaken off the prospect of the end to electronic money-printing, pushing shares higher this morning.

BIS chief Jaime Caruana's warning that unwinding the world's huge quantitative easing programmes may not be smooth (see 8.12am) hasn't caused alarm. Instead, traders are anticipating that the Federal Reserve will maintain its stimulus programmes. Yesterday's weak ISM manufacturing survey, which suggested the US recovery was faltering, is being taken as a sign that Ben Bernanke won't start tightening....

There's also relief that Japan's Nikkei climbed by 2% overnight, reversing some of its recent heavy falls.

• FTSE 100: up 38 points at 6564, +0.6%

• German DAX: up 67 at 8353, +0.8%

• French CAC: up 26 points at 3927, +0.7%

• Spanish IBEX: up 82 points at 8367, +1%

• Italian FTSE MIB: up 199 points at 17257, +1.1%

8.38am BST

Spanish unemployment falls

Just in, the number of people out of work in Spain fell by almost 100,000 last month.

Data released by the Spanish Labour Ministry showed the biggest ever fall in registered jobless for any May. Registered unemployment dropped by 98,265 people, or 1.97%, lowering the total out of work to 4,890,928.

May is typically a good month for employment, with the start of the tourism season meaning more temporary hiring (this data isn't seasonally adjusted).

But still, the size of the bounceback is a welcome surprise. In an average May, unemployment drops by around 55k.

The figures showed that unemployment fell across the economy, and for both men (-2.4%) and women (-1.47%). Most encouraging, youth unemployment fell by 16,735 people (-3.53%) from the previous month.

Spain's secretary of state for employment, Engracia Hidalgo, welcomed the news, and said the Madrid government was committed to delivering a strong economic recovery.

Here's the full statement: El paro registrado ha bajado en 98.265 personas, el mayor descenso en un mes de mayo.

8.12am BST

BIS: Exit from loose monetary conditions might not be smooth

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events across the eurozone and the global economy.

First up... the world's financial markets could face stormy conditions when central banks begin to tighten monetary policy, the head of the Bank of International Settlements has warned this morning.

BIS chief Jaime Caruana said investors and governments need to be ready for rough times. Speaking in Seoul this morning, the general manager of the so-called "central bankers’ bank" warned:

While central banks surely have all the tools necessary to technically engineer an exit and will doubtless do their utmost to communicate properly with market participants, it cannot be taken for granted that the process will be smooth.

Many financial institutions, he warned, could suffer significant losses when central banks decide to return to normality and end their government bond purchase schemes. As Caruana put it:

Authorities and market participants must recognise the challenges inherent in the inevitable and desirable interest rate normalisation and seek to make their financial firms and markets resilient in the face of potential strains.

The speech comes at a time when the world markets are being heavily influenced by speculation over America's stimulus package. Talk of the Federal Reserve 'tapering' its huge quantitative easing programme this summer have driven shares down, while bad economic news has often pushed shares up because further stimulus has looked more likely.

Caruana is worried that those QE packages have driven bond prices up to unsustainable levels where investors don't actualiy get a return for holding the debt. As he puts it:

The term premium – the extra reward for bearing the price risk and inflation risk of holding a fixed rate bond – has flipped into a penalty that the investor must pay.

This graph shows that holding US and German 10-year debt means a guaranteed loss, once inflation is factored in:

Once QE is unwound, those yields will rise as prices fall -- and the impact on banks could be painful, Caruana warned:

A global steepening of yield curves could hit the capital of financial institutions, to the extent that they hold their government’s debt, and worsen debt sustainability.

Caruana's speech is online here: Global liquidity: where do we stand? (including plenty of other graphs).

It's the latest in a series of warnings from BIS over the era of ultra-loose monetary policy. Last month, the global banking body suggested that QE had gone far enough.

As usual, I'll be tracking the latest events through the day....

webTitle: Construction sector sees boost from Help to Buy scheme

fields.standfirst: Output from the construction sector rose for the first time since last October, in a sign that the government's controversial plans to boost the housing market are reviving activity
fields.body:
Housebuilders drove a bounce back in the construction industry last month in the latest sign the government's controversial plans to boost the housing market are reviving activity.

Output from the construction sector rose for the first time since last October, according to the Markit/CIPS UK construction PMI. The news coincided with the latest attack on the government's Help to Buy scheme, this time from the City analyst Albert Edwards, who branded it "moronic" and said it will burden young people with even more debt.

Still, for housebuilders, the scheme appears to be bringing new business after months in the doldrums with Markit's survey suggesting residential building work increased at the fastest pace in more than two years in May.

That helped offset slumps for commercial building and civil engineering and lifted the headline construction output index to 50.8 from 49.4 in April, just pushing through the 50-mark that divides expansion from contraction. The index remained below its long-run series average of 53.9.

The report suggested that higher construction output was driven by a "robust and accelerated" expansion of residential activity. The increase in house building work was the fastest for 26 months.

That growth echoes reports from housebuilders such as Barratt Developments and Bovis Homes that trading has picked up after the government announced plans in the budget to help struggling house buyers.

The Help to Buy scheme offers taxpayer backing for up to £130bn worth of mortgage lending. But the scheme has faced criticism as risking creating another housing bubble in the UK. Warnings from from Bank of England governor Mervyn King and the International Monetary Fund were echoed this morning from Edwards, strategist at Société Générale.

He decries a "moronic policy" that will lead to the "indentured servitude of our young people."

He comments: "What makes me genuinely really angry is that burdening our children with more debt (on top of their student loans) to buy ridiculously expensive houses is seen as a solution to the problem of excessively expensive housing."

Despite the May revival in construction there was little sign of any new jobs in the sector. Markit's survey suggested employment levels were broadly unchanged and staffing levels have failed to rise in each of the past three months with survey respondents citing subdued underlying demand.

"While the latest survey provides some hope that rising construction output will support UK GDP in the second quarter, the sector remains unlikely to contribute positively to labour market conditions," said Tim Moore, senior economist at Markit.

webTitle: Rentokil rises on talk of £400m sale of office maintenance business

fields.standfirst: Report suggests US private equity group interested in divisions of both Rentokil and Balfour Beatty
fields.body:
Rentokil Initial has risen nearly 3% on reports of a possible offer for its office maintenance business.

US private equity firm Clayton Dubilier & Rice is considering buying the Rentokil division and merging it with Balfour Beatty's rival operation, according to the Financial Times.

Talks are already being held on the plan, the report said, with a valuation of a higher than expected £400m put on the Rentokil business. Justin Jordan at Jefferies said:

In our sum of the parts Rentokil valuation, we value [the division] at £226m, hence view £400m proceeds as an appealing prospect. While Rentokil has refused to comment, we view this possible disposal as strategically sensible, allowing Rentokil to focus on its two key growth divisions, Textile and Hygiene and Pest, both of which enjoy leading market positions, mid-teen operating margins and structural growth opportunities.

Hector Forsythe at Oriel Securities said:

The proposal to a sale of the two businesses to a single purchaser reduces the probability that a deal can be done. That an article appears in the public domain at this juncture perhaps is an effort to get some price tension into the deal.
Our view is that this is perhaps the most likely route for Rentokil to achieve a disposal of [the division]. It is a business that is performing well in our view. Margins are making progress as the mix changes to a higher concentration on integrated facilities management contracts. There have been notable wins this year and the pipeline is encouraging. Near-term, revenue progression is being masked by action to exit small, single service contracts. These are low margin sales. An exit would remove another non-core business from the Rentokil portfolio and lower group leverage, giving additional flexibility to maintain bolt-on growth in its core activities.

Rentokil is up 2.65p at 91.1p while Balfour Beatty, whose business is said to be worth around £200m, has dipped 1.2p to 231.3p after HSBC cut its target from 285p to 260p.

Meanwhile defence group Cobham is down 13.7p at 272.4p on talk of an institutional investor selling 3.6%, or 39.1m shares. The shares were said to be being offered by UBS to institutions at between 273.5p a share and last night's close of 286p.

webTitle: Royal Bank of Scotland could be split up under commission's plans

fields.bodyText: George Osborne's hopes of a rapid privatisation of Royal Bank of Scotland could be scuppered by the parliamentary commission on banking standards, which is next week expected to discuss whether the bailed-out bank should be nationalised and split into a good and bad bank. The future of RBS was not originally within the remit of the commission, chaired by Tory MP Andrew Tyrie and set up after the Libor scandal. It has been thrust onto the agenda by Tory peer Lord Lawson, who has questioned the chancellor on whether RBS should be broken up. Outgoing Bank of England governor Sir Mervyn King also told the commission he believed the 81% taxpayer-owned bank should be split in two, with the state keeping the "bad" bank. The "good" bank, created to lend to business, could then be privatised. King is understood to have privately told RBS chairman Sir Philip Hampton that he is committed to arguing for a break-up before his term of office ends at the end of June. An early 600-page draft of the commission report is circulating among members, including the Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby as well as Lawson. They have until Friday to table amendments before beginning next week's two-day session to produce the much anticipated final version. Members appear to be divided on whether to reopen the debate about the future structure of RBS in their final report, expected to be published days before Osborne delivers his Mansion House speech to the City on 19 June. Osborne is expected to use the high-profile speech to outline a plan for returning RBS, and the 39% taxpayer-owned Lloyds Banking Group to the private sector following pressure from the International Monetary Fund to devise a "clear strategy" for the two bailed out banks. There were suggestions that the commission could call on Osborne to consider all options and devise a strategy by September. Even the most subtle of references to RBS will present Osborne with a dilemma as he attempts to engineer a pre-election sale of the bank. He has been asked by the Treasury select committee – also chaired by Tyrie – for a report on the cost of breaking up RBS. The Treasury is yet to reply to that request. During his evidence to the commission in February, Osborne said it could cost up to £10bn to nationalise and then break up RBS and that there were "very considerable obstacles" to doing so. On Tuesday a Treasury spokesman said: "As the chancellor has said, we need functioning banks supporting the real economy instead of nursing their wounds, and we will set out the way ahead once the parliamentary banking commission has completed its work." The banking commission declined to comment. According to the BBC, which has reported that the commission is committed to recommending a break-up of RBS, one idea the government is exploring is to transfer RBS's Ulster Bank to the Irish government via Ireland's bad bank, the National Asset Management Agency. Stephen Hester, chief executive of RBS, has questioned whether more taxpayer cash should be poured in to the bank – on top of the £45bn used to buy shares – to strip it of toxic assets. At the bank's recent results, he said: "Clearly, if government, for one reason or another, thought that it was a good use of public money to take some headaches off us, why would we complain about that or why would we refuse to consider it?" But he added: "Of course, there's a separate debate about whether more public money in RBS's direction is necessary or a good thing." Some ideas on the future of RBS are expected to be contained in a document due to published this month by the Policy Exchange thinktank which may also frame Osborne's thinking. At a hearing of the Treasury select committee on Tuesday Richard Sharp, a former Goldman Sachs banker who is joining the Bank of England's financial policy committee, appeared to back the idea of a breakup of RBS. The Treasury select committee is expected to hold a new hearing with Lloyds executives about the failure to sell 632 branches to the Co-operative Bank. The Co-op is working on ways to plug a £1bn capital shortfall at the bank.

webTitle: New Look returns to profit

fields.standfirst: Debt-laden fashion retailer reports profits of £3m, compared with loss of £55m the year before
fields.body:
Fashion retailer New Look has swung back into the black, as sales picked up in the second half of the year.

The debt-laden company eked out £3m of pre-tax profits in the 53 weeks to 30 March, compared with a loss of £55m the previous year.

New Look – which is owned by private equity groups Apax and Permira and founder Tom Singh – finished its financial year with net debt of £1.1bn, following a refinancing that pushes repayment dates back to 2018. That compares with full-year turnover of £1.48bn, up 2.5% on the previous year.

Sales in shops open more than a year declined 0.7% but that masks an improvement in the second half, when they rose 1.7%. New Look also boosted margins by two percentage points, which it put down to "tighter stock controls and lower markdowns".

New Look chairman Alistair McGeorge said: "I am delighted to report that our three-point turnaround plan of cost savings, margin improvement and revenue growth enabled us to deliver strong results and continue to re-invest in our business."

He said the company's long-term goal remained the same: to cut debt through profit growth and strong cashflow.

The company – which has over 1,100 stores across 32 countries – said it plans to develop new markets in eastern Europe and Asia, specifically Russia and China. It aims to open its first shop in China next year.

webTitle: Wolseley loses 3% as European weakness outweighs positive US news

fields.standfirst: Building materials group hit by construction delays in France but UK and US show improvement
fields.body:
In a rising market, building materials group Wolseley stands out with a near 3% fall.

The company reported a 7.9% rise in third quarter trading profits to £150m, with good growth in the US and UK. But investors took more notice of Europe, where its business continues to suffer from the continuing economic crisis. Sales in France fell by 9.2% on a like for like basis due to weak residential construction, and by 4.6% in central Europe. As for the outlook, Wolseley said:

The overall growth rate in May has been similar to the growth rate in the third quarter. The US and UK have continued to grow well, whilst market conditions remain challenging in the rest of Europe.

So the company's shares have dropped 97p to £32.60, making it the leading faller in the FTSE 100. Analyst Andy Brown at Panmure Gordon issued a sell note, saying:

Steady progress from Wolseley with a continuing good performance from the US being partially offset by tough conditions in Europe. Cost control and market share gains remain a feature, contributing to stable margins. While
investors will focus on US housing we believe that there is a lot of good news already in the share price; take profit, sell. The medium term attraction of North America remains in place so any price weakness will prompt us to revisit our recommendation.

Mark Howson at Oriel Securities kept his hold rating:

The trading profit of £150m was at the lower end of what we believe to have been at the lower end of a £150-160m discernible range. Nevertheless, the continued strength of the US and a better third quarter UK performance is likely to keep 2013 consensus expectations unchanged at £650m, although there is pressure on the July 2014 estimates.
Overall, the update is OK'ish but the weakness in Continental Europe going into next year will have to be addressed in forecasts.

Despite Wolseley's decline, the FTSE 100 overall is up 42.19 points at 6567.31, helped by continuing hopes that the US Federal Reserve would keep its bond buying programme on track for longer. Weaker than expected US manufacturing figures on Monday - another factor in Wolseley's fall, perhaps - suggested the Fed would not scale back its stimulus measures in the short term. Comments from one of the Fed's members have also helped. Jonathan Sudaria at Capital Spreads said:

Overnight the US indices managed to claw their way into positive territory as disappointing economic data revived expectations that the Fed will continue its stimulus measures a while longer. Adding to these hopes were some dovish words from Atlanta Federal Reserve President Dennis Lockhart. Although he said that a reduction in bond purchases may start this summer, he tried to down play the point by rephrasing it as more of a recalibration and not a full out exit which the market appears to be fearing.
However, with another raft of US data out this afternoon expected to show a modest improvement, in particular the ADP Employment figure and its ability to shape expectations for [non farm payrolls on Friday], we could quite easily see markets about face if traders feel the data warrants Fed tapering.

Easyjet is leading the risers, up 46p to £12.67, while GKN has climbed 8.9p to 307.2p after UBS raised its target price from 275p to 350p. The bank said:

The acquisitions of Getrag and Volvo Aero have transformed GKN's Driveline and Aerospace divisions and strengthened GKN's strategic position in both of its key markets – aerospace and autos – in our view. We believe those changes, together with GKN's continued focus on efficient cost and cash management, have put GKN in a better position strategically and operationally..
The integration of acquisitions, the weakness in auto production in Europe, and the loss of a large aerospace contract have so far masked these changes. As we progress through 2013 and into 2014, we expect to see a gradual improvement in the performance of GKN's businesses that will reflect the transformation.

webTitle: Billabong shares plunge as private equity suitors pull out

fields.bodyText: Embattled surfwear chain Billabong saw half its value wiped out after the company announced an end to long-running takeover talks. The Australian group said two private equity firms, Altamont Capital and Sycamore, had abandoned plans for a full takeover and were now looking at a deal designed to help pay back its debt. Billabong chairman Ian Pollard said: "The refinancing is intended to provide the company with a comprehensive solution and an appropriate capital structure, allowing it to continue its reform agenda. It's our intention to conclude these discussions as soon as possible while aggressively reducing costs across all of our global operations." Billabong has been buffeted by a strong Australian dollar, which has dented overseas profits, while debts used to fund its international expansion have weighed on the company. Core Billabong brands, which include its namesake and Von Zipper, also appear to have lost touch with the group's core youth market. The company – which has been dealing with takeover approaches for more than a year – has pledged to cull brands and close underperforming stores. The shares took a nosedive after they resumed trading on Tuesday, plunging 41% to A$0.26 – leaving the company worth just A$130m (£86m). Sycamore – which had teamed up with the former head of Billabong's US business – offered A$0.60 cents a share, or A$287m, for the company in April. But reports suggest the firm walked away after its banks asked for more information on the quality of Billabong's earnings. On Tuesday, Billabong ripped up its full-year guidance for the fourth time since December 2012, saying earnings were likely to be 13% lower than forecasts it made in February. The company now expects full-year pre-tax profits before exceptional items of between $67m and $74m. Billabong said it was still looking to sell 70-strong Canadian chain West 49, which it bought just three years ago for $91m, as part of an ill-fated push into the country. Reports suggest parties other than Sycamore and Altamont are also interested in the business. The proceeds of the refinancing and asset sales would be used to repay Billabong's $279m debt pile, but analysts remained unconvinced. Jordan Rogers of Commonwealth Bank of Australia said: "Billabong's balance sheet is again in a fragile position. We don't view the private equity firms as reliable debt providers."

webTitle: Let's get into more debt

fields.standfirst: Australia should conquer its fear of government borrowing. This is a great time to spend on long-term projects
fields.body:
To explain Australia’s debt position the government has commonly compared it to a mortgage. Currently the net debt is around 10% of GDP, which is why Julia Gillard has suggested “our level of debt is the same as a person earning $100,000 a year with a $10,000 mortgage”.

It’s a good line that rather nicely explains the situation. Indeed, it’s a line I suggested the government should have used back in the 2010 election.

While it is a good line, it is also a bit misleading. Although measuring level of debt as a percentage of GDP is sensible and common throughout the world, the government’s income is not GDP. Income – or revenue – is only 23% of GDP.

If we look at the government’s net debt as a percentage of its own income, suddenly that mortgage grows to around $47,400 because government net debt is currently around $161bn, and total revenue is around $350bn. Net debt is approximately 47.4% of the government’s annual income.

The problem with comparing the government’s budget to that of a household is that when you and I worry about our mortgage, we don’t actually worry about the total size of the mortgage. You don’t sit around the kitchen table thinking, “How are we going to pay off this $400,000 debt?”

What people do worry about is the mortgage payments – those fortnightly/monthly payments that must be met.

Here is where the government’s net debt position really comes into focus: net interest payments are around $7.8bn a year.

Now that sounds like a hell of a lot ($21m a day), but it comes in at just under 2.1% of total revenue. To go back to the analogy of a person on a $100,000 income, that is the equivalent of having to pay $2,084 a year, or $80.15 a fortnight, in mortgage payments.

Not a lot.

Even if we use the gross debt amount of $12.9bn, the payments come in at only 3.45% of the government’s revenue.

But here’s the very interesting thing. Back in 1998-99 the government’s level of debt was approximately the same in terms of both GDP and a percentage of total revenue. Except instead of having to pay 2.1% of revenue in interest payments, it had to pay over twice that – around 5.7%.

Why was this?

Well if you go over to the Australian Office of Financial Management website, you’ll see that last week the government raised $700m in bonds at the interest rate of 2.82%. This in effect means the government borrowed $700m at an interest rate of 2.82%. Back in 1999 the government would have had to pay an interest rate of around 5.14%.

That adds a heck of a lot to the interest payments.

This brings up another issue. In this past year, the government has been able to borrow money cheaper than at any time in the past 45 years.

Being scared of debt now is a bit like a householder not wanting to take out another mortgage to renovate their house because the interest rate is too low.

The price the government will have to pay for debt will inevitably go up. But at the moment we’re in a very unique situation of being one the few AAA rated currencies. And because the US and other major nations have bond yields at record low rates, Australia’s are also low.

This won’t continue forever.

Borrowing now to finance long-term infrastructure – train lines, major highways, ports, airports - is a smart play.

Clearly we don’t want to be silly about it. One of the reasons the government is able to borrow at such low rates is because our debt is low compared to the rest of the world.

Our fear of debt, engendered by one side of politics and sections of the media, has blinded us to the opportunities available. 

Adding to our debt to funnel money to consumers, through tax cuts for example, would be madness – like taking out an extra mortgage to pay for a holiday. But borrowing at low rates to fund long-term infrastructure is like taking out an extra mortgage to build another bedroom onto your house – it adds capacity and value to your home.

And, if you can afford it now, you’ll be kicking yourself if in five years' time rates are double.
